Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effectiveness of Cognitive Aids in Surgical Settings

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomised clinical trial was conducted in a simulation setting with surgical teams from four hospitals in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility required participants to be part of a surgical ward team.

Intervention.evidence: Teams were randomised to manage three simulated deteriorating patient scenarios with or without cognitive aids.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the impact of cognitive aids on adherence to best practices in managing deteriorating postoperative patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the percentage of omitted critical management steps, assessed immediately post-scenario.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not feasible due to the intervention's nature.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Fifty surgical teams were randomised, with 25 teams in each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Cognitive aids reduced omitted critical management steps from 33% to 10%, a 70% reduction (P < .001). This effect was significant in multivariate analysis (odds ratio, 0.63; 95% CI, −0.228 to −0.061; P = .001).
